name: College Essentials
description: 30 words commonly encountered in college-level reading

words.definition: Present, appearing, or found everywhere.
examples: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern life.
Coffee shops are ubiquitous in the city.

words.definition: Dealing with things sensibly and realistically.
examples: She took a pragmatic approach to the problem.
Pragmatic solutions are often the most effective.

words.definition: Fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing.
examples: The eloquent speaker captivated the audience.
Her eloquent defense swayed the jury.

words.definition: Showing great attention to detail; very careful.
examples: The meticulous researcher checked every source.
She was meticulous in her preparation.

words.definition: Able to recover quickly from difficulties.
examples: Children are often more resilient than adults realize.
The resilient economy bounced back quickly.

words.definition: Incapable of producing any useful result; pointless.
examples: All attempts to negotiate were futile.
It's futile to argue with her once she's decided.

words.definition: Truthful and straightforward; frank.
examples: I'll be candid with you about the risks.
Her candid assessment surprised everyone.

words.definition: Well-meaning and kindly.
examples: The benevolent donor gave millions to charity.
She had a benevolent smile.

words.definition: Lasting for a very short time.
examples: Fame can be ephemeral.
The ephemeral beauty of cherry blossoms.

words.definition: Having an ability to accurately assess situations.
examples: The astute businessman saw the opportunity.
Her astute observations impressed the panel.

words.definition: Holding firmly to something; persistent.
examples: The tenacious reporter uncovered the scandal.
She was tenacious in pursuit of her goals.

words.definition: Expressed clearly; easy to understand.
examples: His lucid explanation made the concept clear.
The patient had lucid moments between episodes.

words.definition: Using more words than needed; wordy.
examples: His verbose writing tired the readers.
Try not to be so verbose in your essays.

words.definition: Briefly and clearly expressed.
examples: Her succinct summary captured the main points.
Keep your answers succinct.

words.definition: Inclined to lay down principles as undeniable truths.
examples: His dogmatic approach alienated colleagues.
She rejected dogmatic thinking.

words.definition: Having great energy or enthusiasm for a cause.
examples: The zealous advocate fought for reform.
Her zealous efforts paid off.

words.definition: Believing that people are motivated by self-interest.
examples: His cynical view of politics was depressing.
She became cynical after being deceived.

words.definition: Having or displaying passionate intensity.
examples: She was a fervent supporter of the cause.
His fervent speech moved the crowd.

words.definition: Make suffering or a problem less severe.
examples: The medicine helped alleviate her pain.
New policies may alleviate the housing shortage.

words.definition: Make something greater by adding to it.
examples: She augmented her income with freelance work.
Technology can augment human capabilities.

words.definition: Reduce in extent or quantity; cut short.
examples: Budget cuts curtailed the program.
We need to curtail unnecessary spending.

words.definition: Encourage the development of something.
examples: The program fosters creativity in children.
Good teachers foster a love of learning.

words.definition: Examine or inspect closely and thoroughly.
examples: Auditors scrutinized the financial records.
She scrutinized his face for any reaction.

words.definition: Make an action or process easier.
examples: Technology facilitates communication.
The mediator facilitated the discussion.

words.definition: Make less severe, serious, or painful.
examples: Steps were taken to mitigate the damage.
Nothing could mitigate his disappointment.

words.definition: Provide evidence to support or prove the truth of.
examples: Can you substantiate your claims?
The evidence substantiated the theory.

words.definition: Match or surpass by imitation.
examples: She tried to emulate her mentor's success.
The software emulates older hardware.

words.definition: Deduce or conclude from evidence and reasoning.
examples: What can we infer from this data?
I inferred from his tone that he was upset.

words.definition: Restore friendly relations; make compatible.
examples: They reconciled after years of conflict.
How do you reconcile these contradictions?

words.definition: Capable of working successfully; feasible.
examples: Is this a viable solution?
The business is no longer viable.
